An authorization and permit program for hot work operations near or around the regulated substances (chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide) and processes has been implemented at the WWTP.

Contractors performing maintenance or repair on or adjacent to chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide processes are instructed in the hazards of the materials on-site, and documentation is maintained on contractor understanding of training provided as described in the RMP/PSMP. In addition, emphasis is placed on knowing evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency.

The WWTP chlorine and sulfur dioxide system technologies are not confidential and any information regarding the process or process chemistry is available for review in the RMP/PSMP.

Five-Year Accident History

No accidents that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide systems have occurred at the facility in the past five years.

Emergency Response Program

The RMP/PSMP Emergency Action Plan for the Gallup WWTP includes procedures to evacuate. The Gallup WWTP is considered a non-responding facility whose employees will not respond to an accidental release of chlorine or sulfur dioxide. The Fire Department would respond to accidental releases of chlorine or sulfur dioxide.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Planned changes to improve safety include updating labeling of the covered processes as needed, providing additional info

and sulfur dioxide information, technology of the process information, and equipment information.

The PHA completed for this Risk Management Plan (RMP)/Process Safety Management Plan (PSMP) documents the process and the findings to minimize or eliminate hazards, to mitigate the consequences of hazards of any releases or other unplanned events, and to reduce the likelihood of exposure to chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.

Written procedures and information have been developed, implemented, and maintained for the hazardous process, including steps for each operating phase, operating limits, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. All employees involved in working with and around the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems are trained in process and safety procedures.

The mechanical integrity of chlorine and sulfur dioxide process equipment is documented and maintained through maintenance, inspection, and testing programs. In addition, a Management of Change program has been established to ensure proper review of a proposed change to the chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide system.

A pre-startup safety review is performed on new or modified processes to ensure that equipment and construction meet design specifications, procedures and training have been implemented, and hazard analysis recommendations are resolved prior to start-up.

A Compliance Audit Program has also been implemented. The objective of this self-evaluation program is to ensure that a strong Risk Management Program is maintained, implemented, and followed by personnel.

Staff have developed a formal documented system to manage incident investigations and follow-up. Each incident from a covered process that resulted in deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage will be investigated, and an incident investigation report filed in the RMP/PSMP.

Facility Information

The Gallup Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) is owned by the City of Gallup. The City of Gallup has contracted with Jacobs to provide daily management, operations, and maintenance of the WWTP however, the City of Gallup has full legal responsibility for the Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP), including this Risk Management Plan (RMP) and has/retains the authority to make all policy and procedure decisions for this facility.

The WWTP is designed to treat wastewater utilizing chlorine as a disinfectant in the treatment process. Sulfur dioxide is used to neutralize the chlorine before discharge. The WWTP is designed to treat up to 3.5 million gallons per day (MGD) and is located in Gallup, New Mexico.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The Gallup WWTP implements a scheduled preventive maintenance program, including inspection and testing, to minimize the potential for accidental releases. Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work safely and efficiently.

The Gallup WWTP staff are trained only to manage incidental releases related to maintenance and operation activities and the facility is considered a non-responding facility per 40 CFR 68.90. Emergency response to accidental releases is coordinated with the local fire department and local emergency planning committee.

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

The Gallup WWTP utilizes chlorine (regulated substance) as a biocide in the treatment of wastewater. Sulfur dioxide (regulated substance) is utilized to neutralize the chlorine before discharge.
